message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is most likely suffering from benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), which is characterized by sudden dizziness triggered by changes in head position. Canalith repositioning is the most effective treatment, which involves maneuvers to move the displaced otoliths to their correct position in the vestibular system. Oral prednisolone is not indicated for BPPV, and posterior canal occlusion and singular neurectomy are not standard treatments for BPPV.

Canalith repositioning is the treatment of choice for BPPV. Oral prednisolone is not indicated for BPPV, and posterior canal occlusion and singular neurectomy are more invasive procedures that are not necessary for BPPV treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings suggest benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). Canalith repositioning is the treatment of choice for BPPV, which involves maneuvers that move the displaced particles in the ear back into their proper position. Oral prednisolone and posterior canal occlusion are not indicated for BPPV. Singular neurectomy is a surgical option considered only if conservative treatments fail.

Options A, C, and D are not used to treat BPPV.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest that the patient has benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), which is caused by small crystals in the inner ear becoming dislodged and moving into the wrong part of the ear. Canalith repositioning, also known as the Epley maneuver, is the treatment of choice for BPPV. Options A, C, and D are not effective treatments for BPPV.

Oral prednisolone is not an appropriate treatment for BPPV. Posterior canal occlusion and singular neurectomy are more invasive treatments used for persistent or refractory cases of BPPV.

Canalith repositioning is the treatment of choice for BPPV, specifically the Epley maneuver. Oral prednisolone is not indicated for BPPV, and surgical options such as posterior canal occlusion or singular neurectomy are reserved for patients with intractable vertigo.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), which is treated with canalith repositioning maneuvers, such as the Epley or Semont maneuvers. Oral prednisolone is not used to treat BPPV. Posterior canal occlusion and singular neurectomy are more invasive procedures reserved for rare cases that do not respond to canalith repositioning maneuvers.
